column2: P5JS - Exploring Colors with Variables!
What you'll do
In the first part of this activity, you'll learn how to use variables to make P5JS even easier!
Hey, {{user_name}}. Today I want to show you something awesome that I just learned!
First things first - Let's start by opening the editor: https://editor.p5js.org (if you don't have it already opened). Also, login if you can. If you can't, no worries!
Before we learn about variables, let us start by setting up our canvas. We will do this by adding a square into the 'draw()' function. Also, just like before we'll make the shape follow your mouse!
To get the rectangle to follow your mouse you'll type rect(mouseX, mouseY, 20, 20); right below background(255); on line 7. If you hit play, you should see a white box following your mouse.
Next, we will give the shape some color with fill(). To do this start a new line right above rect(), and type 'fill('blue');'. When you hit play, you should notice the square turned blue.
However, if we wanted to use a set color for everything in our sketch, this is where variables would come in handy!

For this sketch we will place our variable above the 'setup()' function on line 1. Go to line 1 in your sketch and type 'x = 'blue''. By doing this you are letting the sketch know that wherever you put x, you actually mean the color 'blue'.
This next part will make things a little more clear. Go to the line that says 'fill('blue');' and delete 'blue' and type 'x' in its place, then play the sketch!
Isn't that awesome? Variables can be a placeholder text or numbers. Here's a fun fact! If the program has a variable is set equal to a text, that text is called a 'string'.

So far, so good. I just want to show you one more thing with variables, that might be helpful. If you haven't noticed, our square still has a black outline. I want to show you how we can use the variable we created to get rid of that outline.
This black outline is controlled through the use of stroke();. That means if we type in 'stroke(x)' a line above fill(x);, the outline color will change to the color we have the variable, x, set too.
Now you'll see the square is all blue. Great job! But what if we wanted the stroke to be a different color from the fill?
We can change the outline color by adding another variable with a new color set to it. Let's go ahead and practice that!
Under our first variable x = 'blue'; go ahead and create a new line and type 'y = 'white';'.
Now, when you play the sketch, the outside of our square is white. Isn't that cool? As you can see variables can be super helpful and make a programmers life easier!
Go ahead and select File and then Save at the top left corner. If you don't have an account just copy and paste your code on a text document to save it.
Phew, now that we got the basics of variables down, next time I'll show you how to create random colors using variables! Bye for now!
